creditline: The John R. Van Derlip Fund
department: Chinese, South and Southeast Asian Art
description: standing female figure with bare breasts, in contraposto pose; wearing tiered conical headdress with wheel on back, necklaces, bracelets, rings, heavy belt, gauzy form-fitting slacks, anklets; figure stands on a graduated base; PL arm down, PR hand upraised
text: The great goddess has many names, but devotees understand her as a personification of supreme feminine power. In Tamil Nadu, her iconography is relatively consistent although she might be called by different names depending on the form of Shiva she accompanies. Her right arm is positioned to delicately hold a lotus or blue lily, her left hand rests gracefully at her side, and her sensuous figure is accentuated by the triple-bend stance. An image of Uma must be present at all temple ceremonies for Shiva, or else the ritual is incomplete.
title: Devi Uma Parameshvari, Great Goddess Uma
